texts.es: Lissette es  una persona muy  emprendedora  la cual  trabaja  en una fabrica  de la  localidad   pero  además  de  este  realiza   piñatas las   cuales  vende  con sus  conocidos, ella  esta  muy contenta de habernos  encontrado  ya que  nos  comenta  que  desea  hacer  crecer  su  negocio  por  lo  que  requiere  realizar  la compra  de  materia  prima  para la elaboración de  las   piñatas  ya  que  desea   seguir  brindado  a sus  clientes  el excelente  servicio que  la a caracterizado.
texts.en: Lissette is a very entrepreneurial person who works in a factory in her town.  She also makes piñatas which she sells to people she knows.  She is very happy to have found us because she tells us that she would like to grow her business.  She needs to buy raw materials for making piñatas because she would like to continue providing her customers with the same excellent service she is known for.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for making piñatas.

loans.name: Arenas Del Mar Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ARENAS DEL MAR” iniciará el ciclo primer en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Cascada, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora María Eugenia es la secretaria. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de helados, tejido de ropa de bebe, tienda de llantas, tienda de barrio, venta de refrescos y gelatinas, carnicería, trenzado de mantas, venta de comida, venta de mantas de alpaca.

La señora María Eugenia, indica que hace tres años y medio que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una asesora que fue a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tienda de barrio, ella cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió por necesidad de trabajo y tener una entrada económica para ayudar a las necesidades del hogar.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el mejoramiento de su espacio de comercialización (compra de mostrador para poder exponer sus productos) este mueble lo comprará de las ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente lo instalará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación en salud y crédito; además de los cursillos abiertos pues las desestreza.
texts.en:
The “ARENAS DEL MAR” community bank is about to start its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Cascada regional office.  The group has nine members and is run by a board of directors of which María Eugenia is the secretary.  The businesses that the members of the group are engaged in are varied and include: selling iced treats, knitting baby clothes, running a tire shop, running a neighborhood store, selling soft drinks and gelatin desserts, running a butcher's shop, braiding blankets, selling food and selling alpaca blankets.

María Eugenia says that she joined Pro Mujer three years ago, having been invited by a loan officer who visited her home.  She currently runs a neighborhood store.  She says that she started her business because she needed work and an income with which to help cover the needs of her household.

The loan that María Eugenia is currently taking out will be used to improve her sales location (she will buy a counter where she can display her products).  She will buy this piece of furniture in the street markets in the city of El Alto and then install it in her sales location.  Her work enables her to make income with which to support her family.  María Eugenia is married and has two children.

When asked her what she likes about Pro Mujer, María Eugenia replied that she likes the health training and the loans.  She also likes the open courses where she can learn skills.

loans.use: to buy a counter

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bananas and avocados

loans.name: El Buen Pastor Group

texts.es: El banco comunal el Buen Pastor esta conformado por 8 integrantes, todos tiene diferentes actividades economicas los integrantes son:  Gloria del Socorro, Juan Carlos, Daneysis Yessenia, Ana Patricia, Martha, Maria Isabel, Catalina, Ana Patricia. Daneysis es la cordinadora del banco comunal la cual se encarga de la responsabilidad y union de los integrantes, tiene por actividad economica una pulperia ubicada en su casa de habitacion del financiamiento comprar productos de consumo diario como: arroz, azucar, leche, pan frijoles aceite.
texts.en: The 'Buen Pastor' (Good Shepherd) community bank has eight members who all have different businesses.  They are: Gloria del Socorro, Juan Carlos, Daneysis Yessenia, Ana Patricia, Martha, Maria Isabel, Catalina and Ana Patricia. Daneysis is the group coordinator.  She is in charge of ensuring the responsibility and unity of the group's members.  Her business is a grocery store which is located in her home.  She will use this loan to buy household staples such as rice, sugar, milk, bread, beans and oil.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, bread, beans and oil

loans.name: 10 Estrellas Del Norte Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “10 ESTRELLAS” iniciará el ciclo primer en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Alto Lima, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Lidia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: hilado de vicuña, venta de chompas y suéteres, venta de chuño y papa, tienda surtida y varios, empanadas, queques y rollos, panadero, elaboración de embutidos.

La señora Lidia, indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una asesora que fue a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de hilado y venta de lana de vicuña, ella cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió por la recomendación de una de sus vecinas, pues ella ganaba mucho dinero y podía cuidad a sus hijos, es por eso que desde hace cuatro años atrás doña Lidia trabaja en este rubro.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el incremento de capital (compra de lana de vicuña) mismo que tendrá que desarrollar un proceso de hilado y posteriormente venderlo en las ferias tradicionales de la cuidad de El Alto los fines de semana. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación en salud y crédito
texts.en:
The “10 ESTRELLAS” (Ten Stars) community bank are about to start their first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Alto Limo regional office.  The group has nine members and is run by a board of directors which has Lidia as its president.  The businesses that the members of the group are engaged in are varied and include: spinning vicuña wool, selling sweaters, selling potato and freeze-dried potato, running a store, selling empanadas, cakes and rolls, and making sausages.

Lidia says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for three years.  She joined through an invitation from a loan officer who visited her home.  She currently has a business spinning and selling vicuña wool.  She says that she started this business on the recommendation of one of her neighbors who earned a lot of money and was able to take care of her children.  Lidia has been in this business for four years now.

Lidia will use the loan that she is currently taking out to increase her capital.  She will raw vicuña wool which she will then spin and sell in the traditional weekend street markets in the city of El Alto.  This work allows her to make income with which to support her family.  She is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Lidia replied that she likes the health training and the loans.

loans.use: to buy vicuña wool

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a 47-year-old, married woman from Bien Unido, Bohol, Philippines. She has been in the sari-sari store (corner store) and fishing business for 20 years now. She is asking for a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy additional merchandise such as canned goods, rice, sodas, etc. for her store and also to buy fishing nets for fishing.

Victoria spends her time supporting her husband in their business with the aim of meeting their financial needs, especially for the school expenses of their children. 

In the future, Victoria hopes to improve their livelihood to gain more income. This will give them the opportunity to continue sending their children to school. With the additional income, Victoria plans on reinvesting and saving for her family's future use.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise such as canned goods, rice, sodas, etc. for her store and also to buy fishing nets for fishing.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is engaged in a sari-sari store (convenience store) business in the community of Talibon, Bohol. She is 51 years old and has one adult son. While her husband is working as a driver, she is busy attending to her customers in her store. 

Elsa would like to expand her inventory by adding more merchandise to her store. She is asking for a loan to buy rice, corn, soft drinks and snack foods. Elsa's loan will make a big difference in her business and will make it more attractive to her customers. Her increased income will provide food for her family and also pay for her electricity.

loans.use: to buy rice, corn, soft drinks and snack foods for her store.

loans.name: Zoila Esperanza

texts.es:
Doña Zoila reside en el municipio de Catarina del departamento de Masaya, comerciante desde hace 15 años, el cual consiste en vender productos entre los que mencionamos plata, perezosa, hamacas, zapatos de varón y de vestir de mujer, entre otros. Ella viaja y sus punto de ventas son la Isla de Ometepe, Puerto Sandino, Malaca toya, sus viajes los realiza cada quince días, que es cuando su clientela le hace los pedidos.

Actualmente esta teniendo varios pedidos por lo que requiere invertir mas a su negocio se presenta a nuestras oficina para solicitar un financiamiento en el que pueda realizar las compras que ella necesita para poder cumplir con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Zoila lives in the city of Catarina in the department of Masaya. She has been a merchant for 15 years. She sells silver, hammocks, men’s shoes and women’s clothing and other items. She travels for work. Her sales stops are la Isla de Ometepe, Puerto Sandino and Malaca toya. She travels every five days when her customers make orders. 

Currently, she has various orders, so she needs to invest in her business more. She came to our office in order to request a loan so that she can make the needed purchases to fulfill her customer’s orders.

loans.use: purchase silver, hammocks, men’s shoes and women’s clothing and other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a bathroom

loans.name: Kombo

texts.en:
Kombo is a 42-year-old, hardworking man living in Tiribe, Kenya. He has a personal goal of expanding his business and educating his children to help them attain better academic qualifications. 

Kombo operates a retail shop business, which is very profitable despite the challenge of customers not paying on time. He has a vision of diversifying his business to include farming and owning a grocery store. Kombo intends to use the loan to buy general merchandise such as shampoo, soaps, maize, wheat flour and sugar for sale. 

Kombo and his wife are blessed with five school-going children. They live happily in their own house although it has no electricity nor piped water. He hopes to proceed well with his business and repay his loan on time.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise such as shampoo, soaps, maize, wheat flour and sugar.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is married with two children. She is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. 

Alicia is a farmer who operates a banana production business to earn a living. She has been doing this for eight years. Every month, she earns 3,000 PHP from this business. She has requested a loan of 4,300 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Alicia has been a member of GDMPC since 2011. In the future, Alicia hopes to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba is from Maloro, Tangub City. She is 30 years old and single. 

To earn a living, Melba provides motor transport services in her local community. Melba has been engaged in this business for five years and earns 8,000 PHP a month. 

Melba joined GDMPC in 2011. She is requesting a loan of 10,600 PHP, which will be used to purchase vehicle spare parts and accessories. 

Melba plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase vehicle spare parts and accessories

loans.name: Gs Gracias A Dios Group

texts.es:
La señora Gladys de 58 años de edad, es viuda vive con sus nietos y dos hijos que están solteros, doña Gladis es una persona muy humilde y dedicada a su negocio, radica en el Tular de nacaome, al sur de Honduras, su casa es muy humilde y se dedica día a día a la venta  de ropa nueva y usada, y también vende cosméticos.
Ella es la líder del grupo solidario Gracias A Dios y esta muy contenta de apoyar a sus compañeros de grupo.
Doña Gladis esta solicitando 5,000.00 lempiras para compra de Camisas, pantalones, ropa interior y faldas, con el préstamo ella desea salir adelante y seguir luchando con su negocio para sostener a su familia.
El sueño de doña Gladis es mejorar su vivienda y ampliar más su negocio.
Susana y Franklin se dedican a sus negocios a tiempo completo ya que son su fuente de ingresos.
San Lorenzo, Honduras - Junio del 2012
texts.en:
Gladis is 58 years old.  She is a widow and lives with her grandchildren and two single children.  She is a very humble person who is committed to her business.  She comes from Tular, Nacaome, in the south of Honduras.  She lives in a very humble home and works every day selling new and used clothing.  She also sells cosmetics.

Gladis is the leader of the 'Gracias a Dios' (Thanks to God) solidarity group.  She is very happy to support her fellow group members.

Gladis is requesting 5,000 lempiras to buy shirts, trousers, underwear and skirts.  She hopes that the loan will enable her to make progress and continue working hard in her business in order to support her family.

Gladis' dream is to improve her home and further expand her business.

Susana and Franklin work full time in their businesses which are their source of income.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - June 2012

loans.use: to buy shirts, trousers, underwear and skirts for her business

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is 38 years old and is married with four children. She works running a variety (sari-sari) store and her husband is a farmer. 

Fe is requesting a loan to buy additional merchandise such as toiletries, milk, coffee, seasoning, rice, canned goods, and noodles. She is hoping to improve her business so she can provide for her children's needs and pay their tuition fees. Fe is hoping that the profit generated from her loan will improve her children's lives.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as toiletries, milk, coffee, seasoning, rice, canned goods, and noodles

loans.name: Pastora

texts.en: Pastora used her last loan to buy feed for her pigs. Her business is successful, so she is now taking on planting vegetables as an additional business. She is taking this new loan to buy fertilizer. In the future, she hopes to be successful in business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Bendicion De Dios Group

texts.es: El banco comunal Bendicion de Dios esta conformado por 10 integrantes los cuales son: Jeronima, Anita, Maura, Abrahan, Maria Mercedes, Cristina, Ana Francisca, Maria, Martha Maria Petrona, Anita es la cordinadora del banco comunal la cual se encarga del buen funcionamiento y coordinación entre los miembros, anita tiene por actividad economica la compra y venta de cerdo ya que es la actividad fuerte de la zona.
texts.en: The Bendicion de Dios communal bank has 10 members. They are Jeronima, Anita, Maura, Abrahan, Maria Mercedes, Cristina, Ana Francisca, Maria and Martha Maria Petrona. Anita is the coordinator of the communal bank. She looks after the good operation and coordination between the members. Anita buys and sells pigs since this is a strong business in the area.

loans.use: purchase and sell pigs.

loans.name: Delma

texts.en:
Delma is 31 years old and married with two children. She is from Migcanaway, Tangub City. For the past five years, Delma has been cooking and selling daily dishes to earn a living. She earns 5,000 PHP a month for her work. Delma joined GDMPC in 2010.

Delma is requesting a 8,700 PHP loan to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make food to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food to sell

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is 53 years old and is married with seven children between the ages of 15 and 25. Two of her children are in school and the others are working.  Alima lives in Coast Province, Kenya. For the past eight years, she has operated a kiosk and she is also a farmer. Despite her advanced age, Alima has shown a great deal of enterprise. Her children contribute to her income and she lives in a semi-permanent house without electricity or running water. 

Alima is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to stock her kiosk with maize flour, sugar, salt, and cooking oil. In the future, she would like to run an additional business to earn more income and rebuild her present house to make it bigger and more convenient for her family.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, sugar, salt, and cooking oil

loans.name: Oyunsuvdiin Buleg Group

texts.en:
Oyunsuvd is a-29-year-old lady who lives with her family in an outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. She started her felt manufacturing business in 2004. She makes felt sandals, felt souvenirs and other products which tourists traveling in Mongolia are interested in buying. In July, Mongolians have the great holiday Naadam, so during this holiday a lot of tourists come to Mongolia. Thus she needs to make more felt products.

Oyunsuvd is requesting a Kiva loan with Transcapital NBFI from Mongolia. This loan will be used to purchase raw materials in order to make more felt products and increase her income during the Naadam holiday.

loans.use: to purchase more felt to make more products.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en: Josefa is from Labo, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 62 years old and is married with five children. To make a living, she buys and sells bananas. Josefa been in her business for 5 years and earns about 6,400 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Josefa joined Kiva partner, GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of 12,600 PHP, which will be used to buy more bananas to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Nafisa

texts.en:
Nafisa is a 31-year-old married woman. She has six children with ages ranging from 3 years to 13 years old. She describes herself to be a social and loyal woman. Nafisa operates a retail kiosk where she sells household items. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in a residential area and her primary customers are local residents.

Nafisa describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds for improving the business. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy maize and wheat flour and other fast selling items to stock into her kiosk. Her business goal is to run a wholesale shop in the future. Nafisa also hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to become professionals.

loans.use: to buy maize and wheat flour and other fast selling items.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 46 years old and married with 4 children. She earns a living by raising ducks and chickens in the Philippines. She has been raising ducks and chickens for 5 years and also earns additional income from clothing sales.

Josephine is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy feeds for her ducks and chickens. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds for her ducks and chickens.

loans.name: Faustine

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de cinq enfants dont trois sont encore à charge, Faustine vend des céréales et du bois de chauffage depuis des années. Elle s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin. Ses clients sont composés des béninois et des nigérians. Expérimentée dans le crédit, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un financement. Ce financement lui permettra de participer à la formation professionnelle de ses enfants et de subvenir à ses besoins. Elle souhaiterait élargir son activité afin d'avoir la grande part du marché.
texts.en: Married and the mother of five children, three of whom are still in her care, Faustine has been selling cereals and firewood for years. She stocks at one of the Benin markets. Her clients are from Benin and Nigeria. She has a credit history, so she requested and obtained a new loan. This loan will allow her to help pay for her children’s professional training as well as her own needs. She would like to expand her business and have a large part of the market.

loans.use: to buy one carload of firewood  and six bags of corn.

loans.name: Enrique Alexander

texts.es: Enrique Alexander de 32 años de edad, casado, de la localidad de chinandega con tres hijos, tiene por actividad ecomonica la compra y venta de cerdos las cuales compro el la aldeas cercanas y distribuyo a clientes, a clientes fijos y eventuales, los cuales entrego a destazadores de cerdos, tiene 6 años de experiencia en el negocio, el fiananciamiento lo quiere para invertir en el mismo
texts.en: Enrique Alexander is 32 years old, married and from the town of Chinandega.  He has three children.  His business is buying and selling pigs.  He buys them in nearby villages and distributes them to customers, both regular and casual, who deliver them to pig slaughterers.  He has six years experience in his business.  He would like this loan to invest in his business.

loans.use: to buy pigs to sell

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is 51 years old and married with six children. He lives in Sebasi, Clarin, Philippines. For the past 12 years, he has been a farmer, planting and harvesting rice to sell in his local community. Alex earns 10,000 PHP each month. He joined GDMPC in 2011.

Alex is requesting an 18,600 PHP loan to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for his next planting. In the future, he wants to save money as a reserve for emergencies and to purchase more farmland.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for his next planting

loans.name: Lodgenia

texts.en: Lodgenia is 54 years old and widowed with four children. She is from Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Lodgenia used her previous loan to purchase the raw materials used in her business. Her business is successful, and she's requesting a new loan to obtain more food items to sell. In the future, Lodgenia hopes to be able to grow her business.

loans.use: to obtain more food items to sell

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda is a 56-year-old resident of Labo, Ozamis City. She provides her 2 children's needs from the little amount of 2,000 PHP she gains monthly from her banana production, which she has been doing for 6 years. 

In 2007 she became a member of GDMPC, and she is applying for a loan at GDMPC micro-finance in the amount of 2,700 PHP to buy fertilizer. She wants to expand her business one day.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
This is Gemma, 40, resident of Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Danilo, a carpenter, and she is a mother to her four children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business.

Gemma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Gemma earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and for the maintenance of her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gemma hopes her business will grow into a mini grocery and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is from Labo, Ozamiz City. She is 43 years old. Evangeline is married and has two children. To make a living, she owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. Evangeline been in her business for 14 years and earns about 14,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2006, Evangeline joined GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of 24,600 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Togtokhsaikhan

texts.en:
Togtokhsaikhan is a 24-year-old young bachelor who lives with his mother, sister and brother-in-law in an outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia.  Currently he works at a local company, but his current income isn’t enough for his living. So he decided to run a taxi business besides his daily work, in order to increase his family's income. He is requesting a 3,640,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) to buy an old taxi from another. 

His goal is that he desires to buy a new apartment for his mother. “I really want to buy a new apartment and improve our living conditions in the future,” he said. He is a very hardworking and honest person who is willing to achieve his goals.

loans.use: to increase his family's income and improve his mother's living conditions.

loans.name: Mueni

texts.en:
Mueni is a 30-year-old woman who is married and a mother to three sons and one daughter. Her husband is a primary school teacher, but the income he earns isn't enough to cover the family's needs. For the past seven years, Mueni has been running a kiosk, and she needs more support to cover the costs. Mueni wants to add stock of maize flour, wheat flour, and sugar, but the amount of money she has isn't enough to pay, so she is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES from Kiva through Yehu. She hopes to increase her income through this loan, and to provide better living conditions for the family. 
Thanks for her efforts together with her husband, all their children are in school.

loans.use: to add stock of maize flour, wheat flour, and sugar.

loans.name: Narcisa Dalila

texts.es: Narcisa Dalila, de 57 años de edad, esta emprendedora tiene por actividad ecomomica mercaderia en general y pulperia tiene 15 años de tener el negocio y lo tiene ubicado de forma ambulante y en su casa, el financiamiento lo quiere para comprar mercaderia como: ropa nueva pantalones, camisas, short, ropa interior y articulos personales la cual distribuye y recupero cada quince dias. Ya que la demanda me ha incrementado por lo consiguiente me beneficia y obtengo mayores utilidades,  gracias al apoyo que  leon 2000 me ha brinddo y el programa kiva con los financiamiento le logrado cumplir sueños y metas personales como terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en: Narcisa Dalila is 57 years old.  This entrepreneur's business is selling general merchandise and running a grocery store.  She has been in her business for 15 years and makes her sales both as an itinerant street vendor and from her home.  She would like this loan to buy merchandise such as new clothing, trousers, shirts, shorts, underwear and personal care products which she delivers and then collects payment on every two weeks.  "My demand has increased which has benefited me.  I now make more profits.  Thanks to the support that Leon 2000 and the Kiva program have given me through these loans, I have managed to fulfill my dreams and personal goals such as finishing building my house".

loans.use: to buy new clothing, trousers, shirts, shorts, underwear and personal care products

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. 

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment. In the future, Susana would like to save enough to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah used her last loan to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Her business has grown and become successful. Sarah is requesting a new loan to purchase fertilizer such as manure. In the future, she hopes to be able to continue to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda is 52 years old and married with three children. Her eldest is 22 years old and her youngest is 18. For the past seven years, Florenda has been a rice farmer. Her husband works alongside her on their farm which is located in Talibon, Bohol, where she lives with her family. Farming is their sole source of income, so Florenda takes good care of her livelihood. 

Florenda is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and pesticide and to pay for labor. Once the needed inputs are available, she will work smoothly on her farm and expects a good harvest. Florenda will use the income generated with her loan for her family’s daily needs and to save and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and pesticide and to pay for labor

loans.name: 15 De Junio Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “15 DE JUNIO” iniciará el ciclo primer en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Alto Lima, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Antonia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: artesanía en zapatos y sombreros, venta de material de construcción, costura de chamarras polar, elaboración de trajes, tejedora de mantas de lana, tienda de abarrotes, tejedora de polainas.

La señora Antonia, indica que es la primera vez que integra una Banca Comunal en Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora que fue a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio venta de material de construcción, ella cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió por el apoyo de su esposo, quien le comentó que la apertura de la tienda apoyaría a generar dinero y podía cuidad a sus hijos.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el incremento de capital (compra de cemento) mismo que comprará de la fabrica y posteriormente venderlo en su espacio de comercialización todos los días. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud y el seguro de vida.
texts.en:
The communal bank “15 DE JUNIO” [June 15th] will begin its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of Centro Focal de Alto Lima. It has nine members and is directed by a board whose president is Antonia. The association members' businesses vary and among them are: making shoes and hats, selling construction materials, sewing fleece jackets, making suits, weaving wool blankets, running a grocery store, and weaving leggings. 

Antonia says that this is her first membership with a Pro Mujer communal bank; she joined at the invitation of a sponsor who came to her house. She now sells construction materials, a business she began with her husband's support. He said that opening the business would help them generate income and take care for the children.

This loan will be used to buy cement from the factory to resell in her shop. This work allows her to generate income to help her family as best she can as she is married and has three children. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responded that she likes the clinic and life insurance.

loans.use: to buy cement.

loans.name: Mech

texts.en:
Mech is 33 years old and married. She is blessed with three children who are attending school. Mech lives with her husband and children in a small village of Baray district, Kompong Tom province. She earns a living by cultivating rice and vegetables to sell. She strives to work hard to provide basic needs and a good education for her children. Mech is currently busy with her rice farming business due to the coming rainfall. She has successfully borrowed and repaid two previous loans from HKL.

Mech is requesting her third loan which she will use to fix her house, parts of which are in ruin because it is so old. She will purchase wallboards and floorboards to replace broken ones. Her loan will be sufficient for Mech to fix her house on time and she hopes that her loan will provide a comfortable living situation for her family.

loans.use: to purchase new wallboards and floorboards to repair her house

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria is a married woman with three children, ages 15, 13, and 12. She is 42 years old and has operated a sari-sari store (a corner store) for more than a year now. Gregoria sells items like rice, canned goods, and cold drinks to the people in her community. This business provides her with income to cover their expenses. 

Gregoria is applying for a loan worth 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy more items to sell, like rice, canned goods, and soda. In the future, Gregoria hopes to expand her retail business in order to cater to more customers in her locality. She believes that through loans she can augment her stocks and increase her income. Moreover, she wants to keep working in order to continue to send her children to school for a better education, which is really essential for their future.

loans.use: to buy addtional items to sell like rice, canned goods, sodas, etc.

loans.name: Gs Soni I Group

texts.es:
Doña Teresa es una persona muy emprendedora dedicada a su negocio, vive con sus 3 hijos en Choluteca en el sur de Honduras. Ella tiene más de 4 años de tener el negocio de venta de comidas y golosinas.
Doña Teresa el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de refrescos, carnes, pollos y  condimentos, de esta manera incrementara mas sus ventas y así atender mejor a sus clientes.
Con estos fondos espera que su negocio sea más sólido y rentable.
Doña Teresa sus sueños es poder  y darles a sus hijos una  mejor educación 
Manuela se dedica a su negocio venta de ropa nueva  desde hace mas de 3 años en el mercado de esa zona.
Saira se dedica a la venta de licuados y jugo de naranjas. Desde hace mas de 4 años.
Choluteca, Honduras - Junio del 2012
texts.en:
Teresa, an enterprising woman dedicated to her work, lives with her 3 children in Choluteca in southern Honduras. She has been selling prepared foods and sweets for 4 years. Teresa will use the loan to buy soft drinks, meats, chicken, and condiments to increase sales and offer her customers better service. With the funds, she hopes her business will be stable and profitable.

Teresa dreams of a better education for her children.
Manuela has been selling new clothing in the area for more than 3 years.
Saira has been selling fruit shakes and orange juice for more than 4 years.
Choluteca, Honduras - June 2012

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, meats, chicken, and condiments for her business.

loans.name: Chad

texts.en:
Chad's Pet Shop, LLC started as a home-based business in November 2011. Chad's bird breeding experience, love for animals, and dream of opening his own business prompted him to move into a commercial space and open Chad's Pet Shop. 

Chad is confident that his business will prosper as he fulfills a much needed service to the local community. "Thibodaux residents will no longer have to drive more than 30 miles to find a store that provides live pets and pet supplies because my store will offer quality and convenience to the public," explains Chad. Chad's future aspirations for his business is to open another store in the next two to four years, and eventually have three pet retail stores and two grooming/boarding facilities in Southeast Louisiana. Chad will use his Kiva loan for start-up costs and to purchase inventory and other supplies.

loans.use: to pay for start-up costs, inventory such as shelving, and live animals

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is 28 years old and married with two children who are two and seven years old. Both of her children are enrolled in school. For the past three years, Mwanamisi has been running a kiosk in her rural area, selling goods to her neighbors. She works hard to provide for her family and also earns an income selling farm produce. 

Mwanamisi is requesting a 30,000 KES loan through Yehu to buy additional items to sell. This is her first Kiva loan. In the future, Mwanamisi aspires to save money to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy items to sell

loans.name: Sokhom's Group

texts.en:
Sokhom is 42 years old and divorced. She has four children, two of whom are working as paid workers in Thailand. She lives in a rural village of the Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Cambodia. For the past 15 years, Sokhom has been farming a two-hectare plot of farmland to provide for her family. She earns about 140,000 KHR per day.

Sokhom is requesting her first group loan with VisionFund. She and another female member will each receive 1,000,000 KHR. Sokhom is the group leader and will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her dry-season rice. In the future, she hopes to earn more income from her cash crop to provide for a better lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Mafanikio Group

texts.en:
Prisca, who is in her early 40s is single with one child who goes to school. She has been selling shirts, trousers and vegetables for three years now.  She works from 9 am to 7 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzanian which she wants to use for buying more shirts, trousers and vegetables to resell.  Her dream is to one day be able to build her own house. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Mafanikio" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more shirts, trousers and vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Le

texts.en:
Le is a 42-year-old married woman who operates a rice farming business to help her husband earn income for the family. She has been in this business since she was a teenager living with her parents. So, she has many years of experience in this field. Le just owns a few plots of farmland and she plans to expand her land size to yield a good output. 

Due to the lack of capital, she is asking for a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more land for farming purpose. With the help of the loan, Le will be able to improve her current business and thereby increase her household income. She is responsible for a school-aged child who is in need of her daily allowances.

loans.use: to purchase more land for farming purpose.

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en:
Pascal is married with 3 children. His wife is also a maize farmer. He has been a maize farmer for 6 years. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds for seed multiplication and to support labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy cows for providing milk for the family. 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds for seed multiplication and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Eglecerio

texts.en:
Eglecerio is married with 5 children. He is 43 years old and resides at Montol, Ozamis City, Philippines.

Eglecerio is operating a crop raising venture, planting & harvesting corn for sale in the local community to earn a living. He has been in this business for 20 years. Each month, he earns 8,000 PHP doing this type of business.

He requested a loan of 8,300 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Eglecerio joined GDMPC in 2011. In the future, Eglecerio wants to save as a reserve for future emergencies and to purchase another piece of farmland.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 62 years old and from the community of Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has seven children. Her eldest is 29 years old and her youngest is 18. She is engaged in food vending, which is her main source of livelihood. Josefina usually cooks biko (sweetened glutinous rice, mixed with brown sugar, and usually mashed), budbud (slightly sweet sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves and coconut milk), and suman (a rice cake made from glutinous rice cooked in coconut milk and often steamed in banana leaves). 

Josefina wants to increase her production and would like to ask for a loan to buy ingredients like coconut, sugar, and sticky rice. Any income will be used for her family's daily consumption and school fees for her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like coconut, sugar, and sticky rice

loans.name: Marichelle

texts.en:
Marichelle is 29 years old and is single with a child. She is from Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. For over the past three years, Marichelle has owned and operated a motorcycle transport service. She earns 10,000 PHP a month. Marichelle joined GDMPC in 2009.

Marichelle is requesting a 16,000 PHP loan to purchase spare parts and accessories. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase vehicle spare parts and accessories

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Benediction Group

texts.fr: La cliente Pendeza est secrétaire  du groupe de crédit  Bénédiction, Femme dynamique, cliente au 15e cycle de crédit. Elle est mère de 7 enfants. Son mari est actuellement chômeur (sans emploi). Elle est vendeuse de divers. Elle a commencé son business avec son fond propre reçu de son mari, Elle expose ses marchandises au  marché public du secteur Alanine. Environs 8 ans, elle exerce cette activité génératrice de revenu.  Avec le crédit de l’IMF Hekima, la cliente  souhaite accroitre son chiffre d’affaire en achetant les articles divers (Omo, sucre, pétrole, lotion de beauté, Fanta, souliers, etc.). Le  défi  actuel  dans son activité, c’est la multiplicité de taxes dit-elle. Dans l’avenir, elle ambitionne accroitre son entreprise, construire confortablement, scolariser ses enfants et  voir son mari trouver du travail. Elle remercie l’IMF Hekima, pour les crédits réguliers qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle, car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux multiples besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: The borrower Pendeza is the secretary of the loan group Bénédiction.  A dynamic woman, she is on her 15th loan cycle.  She is the mother of seven children.  Her husband is currently unemployed.  She sells various items.  She started her business with money that her husband gave her.  She makes her sales at the public market in the Alanine sector.  She has been earning money with this type of work for about eight years.   With money from the IMF Hekima loan, this borrower hopes to increase her turnover by stocking up on various items (Omo detergent, sugar, gasoline, cosmetic lotions, Fanta, shoes, etc.).  She says that presently, the challenge in this type of work is the amount of taxes.  In the future, she hopes to grow her business, improve the comfort of her home, educate her children, and see that her husband finds work.  She would like to thank IMF Hekima for the regular loans that she receives without any collateral.  It is because of these loans that she is able to meet the many needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy various items such as Omo detergent, sugar, gasoline, cosmetic lotions, Fanta, shoes, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Gs Soni I Group

texts.es:
Doña Hegdomilia es una persona muy emprendedora dedicada a su negocio, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos. En Choluteca en el sur de Honduras. Y tiene más de 10 años de tener este tipo de negocio de pulperia.
El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, refrescos, azúcar, café, pan, harina, arroz, frijoles y verduras, de esta manera incrementar más sus ventas. Con el préstamo espera mejorar sus ventas y asi atender mejor a sus clientes. Con estos fondos espera que su negocio sea más sólido y rentable.
Doña Hemigdonia sus sueños es poder  y darles a sus hijos una  mejor educación y ayudar a su familia.
Octavio se dedica a su negocio propio pulpería desde hace mas de 7 años en el mercado de esa zona.
Gustavo se dedica su negocio propio compra y venta de ganado. Desde hace mas de 3 años en varios caseríos de la zona.
Choluteca, Honduras - Junio del 2012
texts.en:
Hegdomilia is an enterprising woman dedicated to her work. She lives with her husband and 4 children in Choluteca in southern Honduras and has been running a grocery store for more than 10 years. She will use this loan to buy corn, soft drinks, sugar, coffee, bread, flour, rice, beans, and vegetables to increase her sales and provide better service to her customers. She hopes her business will be more stable and profitable with this funding.

Hemigdonia dreams of giving her children a better education and helping her family.
Octavio has had his own local grocery store for more than 7 years.
Gustavo has been buying and selling livestock in local villages for over 3 years.
Choluteca, Honduras - June 2012

loans.use: to buy corn, soft drinks, sugar, coffee, bread, flour, rice, beans, and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel currently earns income by operating a goat meat business and a retail kiosk. These are the only sources of income that he has to support his family. He does this work to cover his family’s expenses for food, education, and basic services.

Emmanuel needs a loan to purchase more livestock for resale. His dream is to expand his businesses and purchase a grinding machine in future. This way he will improve his family's quality of life.

This is the third time he has requested a loan from Yehu and the second time he has requested a loan from Kiva. Thanks to Kiva and Yehu for their support.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock for resale.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Lucy is married and has three children. Lucy used her last loan to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Her business has grown and become successful. Now, she is taking a new loan to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee. Lucy he hopes to be able to grow her business more.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is married and has seven children. Five of them attend school. She has been a maize farmer for 13 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She would like to get this loan to buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to reinvest in her business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Vicheka's Group

texts.en:
Vicheka is 30 and is married with one daughter who is still under her responsibility. She lives in a village of the Dambae district of Cambodia where she farms sweet potatoes and rice on three hectares of land. Vicheka has been a farmer for two years and earns around 23,600 KHR per day. She has been with VisionFund for one loan cycle and has successfully paid back her entire loan which enabled her to have decent food. Vicheka is self-confident.

Vicheka is the leader of a three-member group requesting a new loan. She will use her portion of the loan to plow her farmland. In the future, Vicheka hopes to keep her children in school and to have a big, decent house for her family.

loans.use: to plow her farmland

loans.name: Beezandan

texts.en:
Mr. Beezandan, 57, works as a watchman in a primary school. Before this, he used to work as a driver. All of his children moved out from their parent’s house. Now he lives with his wife and nephew in Kherlen, an eastern boundary town in Mongolia. One of his daughters lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Recently, his daughter purchased a plot of land and an old house in the 'ger' district (ger is a Mongolian nomadic tent).  The house needed a complete renovation or repair. Especially, she is planning to replace its windows to double-glazed ones first due to too much heat loss and emissions through the old ones.  But she lacks money to cover the cost of new windows. 

Her father Beezandan decided to help his daughter to repair her home. She believes her house will become warmer and the cost of coal will be cut notably. Although Mongolia has the lowest population density in the world, it is one of the most polluted countries in the world.  This is due to the long and cold winters where temperatures frequently go below -40C (-40F) even in the cities.  Also, in winter, many parts of the country are extremely cold and are known to have snow storms.  Both homes and nomadic tents burn a lot of fuel and emit huge amounts of pollution every night from families just trying to stay warm.  As well, the extremely toxic smoke from the cars is a main reason of Mongolia's air pollution. 

In response to this, Credit Mongol offers Green Loans to their clients to make home improvements that reduce heat loss, improve heating systems and to buy the cars running on natural gas. The loan Beezandan is taking will be used to cover the cost of the new double-glazed windows for his daughter’s house.

loans.use: To cover the cost of new double-glazed windows for his daughter’s house

loans.name: Hamid

texts.ru: Hamid 23 qoda. On jivet v Baku regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Hamid ne jenat i ne imeyet detey. Uje 3 qoda kak Hamid zanimayetsya prodajey loshadey. On pokupayet loshadey kogda oni bivayet malenkimi, potom koqda oni vzrosleyut on prodayot ix. Tem samim on zarobativayet dengi dlya soderjaniya sebya i svoyey semyi. Hamid seychas nujdayetsya v 1500 AZN chtobi kupit korm dlya loshadey dlya zimi. Hamid xochet razvit svoy bizness i uvelichit kolichestvo loshadey v budushem.
texts.en: Hamid is 23 years old. He lives in the Baku Region together with his relatives. Hamid is single, without children. For three years, he has been selling horses. He buys young horses, raises them and then resells. This is how he earns a living for himself and his relatives. At present, Hamid needs 1500 AZN in order to buy winter feed for his horses. Hamid would like to expand his business and increase the number of horses in the future.

loans.use: to buy horse feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Batzaya

texts.en:
Batzaya is 24 and lives with her husband, parents, and a son in an apartment she owns in Darhan province, Mongolia. Her husband works for a mining company in South Gobi province and her father works as a repairer. Batzaya used to be a shop assistant at her sister’s shoe store and she worked on salary. In January 2012, she started her own business and rented a space to retail shoes. Her mother helps with her business. Batzaya started her business with 1,000,000 MNT in working capital and now has increased her working capital to 5,000,000 MNT. Batzaya already has many regular costumers and wants to expand her business as in the summer product demand is high and she would like to purchase more merchandise to sell.

Batzaya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy summer shoes for 1,500,000 MNT, children clothing for 2,000,000 MNT, and fund transportation costs with 300,000 MNT. She is a hardworking and good natured woman.

loans.use: to buy summer shoes, children clothes, and pay transportation costs

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is married with 3 children. Judith is 36-years-old and resides in Cabungaan Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Judith used her last loan to have additional capital for a lumber business. Her business is successful. She is taking a new loan for her transport business to purchase spare vehicle parts and accessories. In the future she hopes to be able to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare vehicle parts and accessories

loans.name: Junie

texts.en: Junie  is  52  years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 7 children. Junie  has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys & sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. Aside from that he also sells viand like adobo, fried chicken and kare-kare. He had this business for 6 years.He requested a loan for 8,000  to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. Junie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Junie hopes to improve his business for the education of his children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items like beans, kejje and onions

loans.name: Weldita

texts.en:
This is Weldita, 51, resident of Cavite, Philippines. She has one child. She manages their household while operating a business.

Weldita runs a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Gemma buys products at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She brings in a minimum of Php600 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory, and to service her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Weldita hopes to expand her business through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. She can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God as they study together.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and products.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie is married and has four children. All her children are enrolled in schools. She has been a maize farmer for 3 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. Sophie would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest seeds, and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to the pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Batlut

texts.en:
Batlut, 52, lives with her husband and four children in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Tosontsengel, Mongolia. Her husband is a disabled man who receives social welfare from state. Batlut started her business cutting organic hay with a rental tractor in 2011. Her husband and children help with her business. She sells her organic hay to local herders. Her business is sustainable and she has already gotten many regular customers. But, her business income is not sufficient to provide for her family.  

Batlut wants to expand her business. Therefore, she needs to buy her own tractor. She is hardworking and a good natured woman. She said, "I have worked for my children's future. I want to increase my business income in order to provide enough money for my family." She is requesting 2,200,000 MNT to buy her own tractor to use in her business.

loans.use: To buy her own tractor.

loans.name: Benediction De Dieu Group

texts.fr:
Mr  GUIBRINA est le représentant du groupe BENEDICTION DE DIEU. Il est marié et père d’un enfant. L’enfant a 02ans et ne va pas à l’école. Il a 03 personnes en charge.

Mr vend des verres DURALEXE  depuis 02ans. Il s’approvisionne au Ghana et au Nigeria. Ses clients sont les gérants de maquis, bar et kiosque.

Il veut s’acheter  08 cartons de verres.

Il utilise ses bénéfices pour améliorer  son activité et agrandir son hangar. Mr ambitionne préparer la scolarisation de son enfant, et construire dans sa futur parcelle qui sera loti bientôt.
texts.en:
Mr. Guibrina is the leader of the BENEDICTION DE DIEU group.  He is married and the father of one child.  The child is two years old and does not go to school.  He has three people in his care.

Mr. Guibrina has been selling Duralexe glasses for two years.  He gets his supplies in Ghana and in Nigeria.  His customers are managers of bars and kiosks. 

He wants to buy 8 cases of glasses.

He will use his profits to improve his business and to enlarge his storage space.  Mr. Guibrina’s ambition is to prepare for his child’s education and to build on his future plot of land which will be divided out soon.

loans.use: to buy 8 cases of glasses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items like meat and beans.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda provides transportation services within her town using her motorized tricycle. She is married and has three children ages three, six and eight. She and her family live in San Jose, Talibon, Bohol.

Merlinda is in need of a loan so that she can buy spare parts and pay the vulcanizing fee for her vehicle. The tricycle is her main source of livelihood, so once it is fixed, she can earn the daily income needed to meet her family's needs. Any additional income will pay for her children's schooling and the pursuit of possible new business opportunities.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and pay for vulcanizing.

loans.name: Ganijon

texts.en: Ganijon is cute, brainy and kind-hearted. He is a young and reasonable person. Ganijon has a lot of friends. His friends love him very much and always help him in his deals. For more than 12 years he has been busy with animal husbandry. His business has developed year after year as he works very hard. Ganijon buys cattle, cares for them and then sells them to the local people. He wants to develop his business further to earn more income. He is asking for a loan to buy young cattle to expand his business. If you want to help anybody, please, help Ganijon. He awaits your help and support.

loans.use: To buy cattle for his developing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Rim

texts.en:
Residing in a rural area located in the Ponhea Krek district of Kompong Cham province, Cambodia, Rim is 37 years old and married. She has four dependent children, three daughters and one son, all of whom are still in school. 

Rim is a farmer who has been growing rice and planting potatoes for 10 years. Rim received her first loan from VisionFund in 2011, and completely repaid the entire loan. The past loan has helped her family make a better living. Now she can earn about 25,000 KHR per day. Rim is applying for a new loan of 1,500,000 KHR to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to increase the amount of land suitable for growing more potatoes so that she can earn more profits.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more coconuts and green banana to resell

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie is married and has two children. Both of them are still young. She has been a maize farmer for six years. Her husband is also a maize farmer.  She would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to save more.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is married with two children, both of whom are still young. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She has been a maize farmer for 10 years. She would like a loan to buy more seeds and pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to increase her savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Savan's Group

texts.en: Savan, age 28, is a married mother of one dependent son living in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. On her two hectares of farmland, she has been growing paddy rice and planting watermelons and cucumbers. She has been in these businesses for ten years. Her main challenge is the crop yields which have been destroyed by flooding in the past year. This is the second cycle for Savan with KIVA’s partner, VisionFund. She has successfully paid back her first loan, which enabled her to build a proper house for her family. With the other two members of the group which she is leading, Savan is applying for a loan of 1,200,000 KHR. One member is requesting a loan for 1,400,000 KHR and the other is seeking a loan for 800,000 KHR. With this loan, Savan is going to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland. In the future, she hopes to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Eliezer

texts.en:
Eliezer is married with five children aged between 12 and 32. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to use this loan to buy more seeds and pay for the labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy a cow.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody, 30, is a resident of Cavite City, Philippines. She has two children with her husband, Leopoldo, a security guard.  Together with her husband and children, she manages the household while running her business.

Melody runs a variety store next to her house. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos' worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Melody makes a profit by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling items individually at retail prices. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 600 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue to run her business, Melody is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and to maintain her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Melody hopes her business will grow into a mini grocery store and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education due to her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock to sell in her store.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married and has six children, between the ages of 5 and 15. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he would like to reinvest in the same agriculture business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Marcelinda

texts.en:
Marcelinda is a farmer in the town of Talibon, Bohol. She is 57 years old, married and has seven adult children.
She has been farming corn and rice for 30 years now. She is also engaged in fishing and crab-catching businesses. Marcelinda's husband is helping her in their business. Marcelinda  would like to improve her income by improving her fishing activity. She is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and crab traps which will enable her to be more productive and to catch more crabs. Her profit will allow her to buy nutritious food for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and crab traps

loans.name: Claudio

texts.en:
Claudio is a 43 year-old married man residing in Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. Claudio has run a motorcycle business for 20 years. He is also in a farming business where he grows rice. 

Claudio is asking for a loan worth 5000PHP to buy spare parts for motorcycle repair and to buy fertilizer for the plants in his farm. 
In the future, Claudio aims to improve his motorcycle business and farming to generate more income so that he will able to meet the needs of his family and for the education of his four children, ages 19, 17, 14 and eleven. He believes that education is really important for a better future.

loans.use: to buy spare motorcycle parts and plant fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Kumba

texts.en:
To meet his household's diverse needs, Kumba sells clothes in a boutique. He also farms to supplement his first business. He has been in this business for over fifteen years in this region. He buys his supplies from a region in Kenya. Thanks to the revenue that this business generates, he helps cover his household expenses.

To meet the needs of his burgeoning customer base, Kumba is requesting a second loan from both Kiva and Yehu. Kumba dreams of opening a new boutique and hiring an employee in the future. This loan will enable him to purchase more bundles of clothes to stock his boutique.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of clothes.

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Pol is 60 years old and a humble villager living in Baray district of Kompong Tom province. He is married and has eight children - two married children and six single children. He is a very hard-working man who is eager to raise his family out of poverty and get ahead in his businesses. He is involved in a farming business, primarily growing rice for daily sustenance and for sale. At the same time, he raises a few piglets for fattening in his backyard. Some of his teenaged children help him in managing the two businesses.

To improve his business and earn a better living, Pol is requesting a loan of KHR 2,000,000 to purchase a used motorbike for his business and household transportation needs. He is very grateful for the loan granted because he will be able to go a long way.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorbike for his business and household transportation needs.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is married and has six children. He has been a maize farmer for 10 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy more plots for growing maize.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Rommel

texts.en:
Rommel is a 37-year-old married man with four children. The oldest child is about 16 years old and the youngest is seven. Rommel's wife works as a house helper in the neighborhood.

Rommel is a farmer and at the same time a carpenter working in San Jose, Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. Rommel has been growing rice for 20 years now. Rommel joined CEVI hoping that he could get financial support for his business. He is asking for a loan worth 4,000 PHP, which he will use to finance his farm and for the maintenance of equipment used in the rice field such as the tractor and thresher. In addition, to he wants to buy additional materials for carpentry such as nails and other things. In the future, Rommel hopes to improve his business in order to experience the fullness of life together with his family.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of equipment used in the rice field such as the tractor and thresher

loans.name: El Rapha Group

texts.fr:
Mr  HAMADO est le représentant du groupe EL RAPHA. Il est célibataire sans enfant. Personne  ne va à l’école. Il n’a personne en charge.

Mr vend des habits prêt à porter (maillots, survêtements  complet)  depuis 06ans. Il s’approvisionne au marché de secteur 10. Ses clients sont les hommes.

Il veut s’acheter  10 douzaines de maillots et survêtements.

Il utilise ses bénéfices pour renforcer  son activité. Mr ambitionne effectuer des voyages à l’étranger pour s’approvisionner.
texts.en:
Mr. Hamado is the leader of the  EL RAPHA group.  He is single and has no children, so there is no one who attends school.   He has no one else in his care. 

Mr. Hamado has been selling ready to wear clothing (jerseys, warm-up suits) for six years.  He gets his supplies at the market in sector 10.   His customers are men. 

He wants to buy 10 dozen jerseys and warm-up suits. 

He will use his profits to build up his business.  Mr.  Hamado would like to be able to travel abroad to get buy his merchandise.

loans.use: to buy 10 dozen jerseys and warm-up suits.

loans.name: Soeurn's Group

texts.en:
Living in the rural Dambae District of Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia, Soeurn is 53 years old. She is married and has three children, including one son who still needs her support as he earns minimal income as a farmer. Soeurn has been planting potatoes on three-hectare of farmland for 25 years. The main challenge for her is the dropping price of potatoes in the market and her children's sickness.

This is the second loan cycle for Soeurn and the first loan for her other two members. She has paid back her first loan which has helped her to make a better living and earn about 27,000 KHR per day. She and one of her group members are each requesting a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each while another one is applying for 500,000 KHR.

As the group leader, Soeurn is going to use her loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes that price of potatoes will increase and she can receive more crop yield so that she can earn more profit.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu is married and has four children. He has been a maize farmer for nine years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to reinvest in the same business of growing maize.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Tsevelmaa

texts.en:
Tsevelmaa, 40, lives with her husband and her two children in an apartment she owns in Khovd province, Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business. Her elder son is a kindergarten student. She recently adopted a child. 

Tsevelmaa started her garment retail business in 2000.  Her business is sustainable and she has many regular customers and suppliers. Starting this year, she has begun to sell wool and cashmere products. She wants to expand her business. She was able to buy an apartment due to her business profits. In the future, she plans to buy a hybrid car.  Tsevelmaa is a hardworking woman. She is requesting 5,000,000 MNT to purchase a hybrid car for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a hybrid car for her family.

loans.name: Marie Alice

texts.en:
Marie Alice is married with no children. She has been a maize farmer for eight years. Her husband is also a maize farmer.
