texts.en:
Mesaidi is a 36-year-old married woman and mother of five children. Three years ago, she opened a tailoring shop to contribute to her household’s expenses. She says that this is the only business she depends on. Throughout the years, she has succeeded in building a sound reputation among tailors in her town.

Mesaidi is applying for a loan to buy clothing materials and sewing threads. As demand for her services increases, Mesaidi needs to maintain the good quality she has been offering. With the money left from the loan, she will invest in farming to earn money to cater toward the little expenses.

loans.use: to buy clothing materials and sewing threads.

loans.name: Fe Y Amor 3 Group

texts.en:
Dominga is the coordinator of her group, Fe y Amor (Faith and Love) 3. Her group is located in Santiago, an area famous for tobacco and beef production, the second biggest city in the Dominican Republic. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children. She says that her most difficult challenge is raising her children. She enjoys cooking and spending time with her family.

Dominga is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for three years, started with her first loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying clothes, underwear, cosmetics and shoes. She will save the profits and also use the money to pay for her family's expenses. She dreams of having her own house and improving her business.

loans.use: To buy various products (cosmetics, clothes, shoes, etc.).

loans.name: Fatim

texts.en: Fatim is 22 years old and lives in the Jacob Town area. She is single, and stopped her education in the ninth grade. For the past six years she has been involved in the sale of charcoal and other goods. Her main challenge is price increases. She started this business with money from her friends. She will use the loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. She will use the profits to pay her house rent and one day would like to own her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is married and has 5 children. She is 53 years old and resides in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Evelyn cultivates bananas and cassava for to earn a living and she's been in this business for 10 years.

Each month, Evelyn earns 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business. She requested a loan of 23,800 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. In 2009, Evelyn joined GDMPC. In the future, Evelyn wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en: Abbas is a Lebanese single man. He’s 31 years old. He’s really attached to his parents and sibling. Cooperating together, Abbas and his family were able to cover their heavy living expenses in order to live a respectable life. Abbas started his business at an early age. He had to work with great professionalism to prove that he’s a necessary support for his family. Abbas started his own work in 1998. He has been working as a car mechanic in his own garage and has gained a fair number of customers asking for his services. Today, he’s asking for a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to buy more mechanic tools for his business in order to respond rapidly to his clients’ problems. He believes that acting properly is really essential to attract more and added customers. In the future, he plans to open his own car showroom.

loans.use: to buy more mechanic tools for his business.

loans.name: Sarhan

texts.en: Sarhan is a 52-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and four children (three of them are still attending school). He has owned a car repair shop since 1992. His job consists of repairing the bodies of vehicles. Serhan owns a small apartment and, in order to get additional income, he decided in 2005 to rent it out up till now. Today, he is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a car and perform the needed smithy work on it (repainting it and repairing the damaged components) in order to resell it in good condition and make a fair profit. In the future, he is planning to open a bigger store to buy and sell spare car parts.

loans.use: to purchase a car and perform the needed smithy work on it.

loans.name: Fouad

texts.en: Fouad is a 50-year-old Lebanese married man. He lives with his wife and two children. He really loves his family and strives to work really hard to be able to offer them a fair way of life far from life's complications and problems, especially after being the only one responsible for them. Fouad started his business in 1982. He has owned a discotheque and has his own loyal customers always asking for his items since he has a huge variety of items. Fouad believes that acting properly will help him attract added clients and stay in good relation with them. Today, he needs to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase CD's and DVD's for his business. He confirms that this step will increase his sales and revenues, and thus better his way of life. Sarhan is very ambitious and looks forward to earning higher income to better support his family.

loans.use: to purchase CD's and DVD's for his business.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is married with six children. She has been a maize farmer for 10 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, support seed multiplication, and pay labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to buy more plots of land for maize growing.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Caminando Hacia El Progreso 1 & 7 Group

texts.en:
Maria is one of the members of the group Caminando Hacia el Progreso (Walking to the Future) 1 & 7. This group is located in a rural community surrounded by sugarcane fields in the outskirts of San Pedro de Macoris. Maria will be sharing in a 174,500 DOP loan the group is applying for from Esperanza.

Maria makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and a child. For the past four years she has operated a beauty salon where she serves her clients and sells different products. She started her salon with her own capital after saving for a while.

Maria is excited to be a part of this third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan portions and grown her business. She plans to use her loan to invest in her salon by buying hair and beauty products, cosmetics and other beauty supplies.

Maria says that her most difficult challenges are improving her business and helping her family. Nevertheless, she plans to continue enjoying working in her salon.

loans.use: to buy hair and beauty products, cosmetics and other beauty supplies.

loans.name: Salley

texts.en: Salley is 46 years old and lives in Jacob Town. She is married and has four children between 10 to 24 years old. All of them are in school and live at home. For the past fifteen years she has been selling used clothes in the local market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. Salley hopes to send her children to quality schools and build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Eveline

texts.en:
Eveline is married with six children aged between 8 and 19. All of them go to school. She has grown Irish potatoes for seven years. She would like this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds, and pay for the labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she plans to expand the area she has been farming.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Cyprien

texts.en:
Cyprien is married with six children. His wife works as a farmer. He has grown Irish potatoes for 10 years. He would like to get this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, Cyprien plans to farm a larger area, and build a commercial building in the trading center.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and seeds, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Adrien

texts.en:
Adrien is married with three children aged between four and twelve. His wife works as a farmer. He has grown Irish potatoes for 12 years. Adrien would like this loan to buy fertilizers and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand his farming area and buy a cow to provide milk for the family.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and seeds, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Edison

texts.en:
Edison is married with four children. Three of them attend school. His wife works as a farmer. Edison has farmed Irish potatoes for 20 years. He would like this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand his farming area and pay school fees.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and seeds, and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Gonzalo

texts.es:
Gonzalo estudió hasta la secundaria y actualmente percibe ingresos de su trabajo como chofer por más de doce horas al día y hasta altas horas de la noche ya que debe cubrir los gastos de educación, alimentación y pago de servicios básicos de su familia.
Es por eso que solicita el crédito para el mantenimiento anual de su vehiculo (chequeo de liquidos, frenos, llantas) ya que es el único que solventa los gastos de su familia y su vehiculo es su herramienta de trabajo.
El es casado y tiene dos hijos que están en etapa escolar , viven en casa de sus padres ocupando tres habitaciones , la casa esta ubicada en la zona bajo Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz.
Es la segunda vez que trabaja junto a IMPRO y la primera vez junto a KIVA.
texts.en:
Gonzalo studied up to secondary school and currently earns income working as a driver more than twelve hours daily well into the night because he must cover his family’s basic education, food and utility costs.

This is why he’s asking for a loan to provide his vehicle’s annual service (fluids check, brakes, tires) since he’s the only one who covers his family’s expenses and his vehicle is his work tool.

He’s married and has two children who are school age.  They live in his parents’ house occupying three rooms.  The house is located in the city of La Paz’s Bajo Llojeta zone.

This is the second time he’s worked with Impro and the first with Kiva.

loans.use: to service his taxi.

loans.name: Georges

texts.en: Georges is a 40-year-old Lebanese single man living with his parents and two siblings (one of whom is working) and a relative. He, together with his family, works continually to manage expenses. They all depend on each other especially when facing complicated problems. Georges has been working as a bus driver since 2006 and has his loyal customers. His job consists of transporting customers from town to town upon request. Today, he wants to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to perform the needed maintenance on his van; otherwise he may lose his loyal and trusty customers. This is how Georges works every day to satisfy his family needs. Since it is summer time, this will help Georges organize some extra trips so he can increase his revenues by at least 20%.

loans.use: to perform the needed maintenance on his van.

loans.name: Justin

texts.en:
Justin is married with 12 children. He has been a maize farmer for 13 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to reinvest in the agricultural sector by growing more maize. 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married with two children aged two and a half and fourteen. The oldest attends school.

For the past four years Emmanuel and his wife have farmed maize. He is applying for a 892,500 RWF loan from UOB to buy more seed and pay for labor on his farm in order to realize the best harvest he can. With his profits he plans to pay school fees and renovate the family’s house.

As of 2009 the agriculture sector has accounted for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans. Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations.

For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seed and pay for labor on his farm.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is married with four children. His wife works as a farmer. He has grown Irish potatoes for 10 years. He would like this loan to buy fertilizers and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand his growing area and buy another hectare of land.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married with three children aged between five and ten. His wife works as a farmer. He has grown Irish potatoes for 15 years. Emmanuel would like this loan to buy fertilizers and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been farming.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Frederic

texts.en:
Frederic is married with four children. His wife works as a farmer. Frederic has grown Irish potatoes for seven years. He would like this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds, and pay for the labor needed to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand his growing area.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and seeds, and pay for labour costs.

loans.name: Joyitas De Oro Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “JOYITAS DE ORO” iniciará el ciclo decimo octavo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Candelaria es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: comerciante de papa y chuño, artesanía en chompas, venta de ropa, venta de celulares y técnico, venta de salchipapas, zapatería, venta de calzados, tienda de barrio, kiosco de cafetería.

La señora Candelaria, indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de su cuñada. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de papa y chuño ella cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió  porque no tenía dinero y quiso ayudar a su esposo a generar recursos, mediante la venta de productos del altiplano.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el incremento de capital (compra de papa u chuño) mismo que comprará del área rural y posteriormente lo venderá en las ferias tradicionales de la cuidad de El Alto. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella vive en concubinato y tiene cuatro hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The communal bank Joyitas De Oro is starting its 18th loan with Pro Mujer, which belongs to the regional office of Villa Exaltación. It comprises nine members and is run by a board of directors. Candelaria is the board President. The members of this communal bank have several types of businesses, such as selling potatoes and chuño (a traditional freeze-dried potato product), making traditional sweaters, selling clothing, selling cell phones and technology, selling salchipapas (a sausage and potato dish), shoe repair, selling shoes, a neighborhood store, and a coffee-shop stall.

Candelaria says she joined Pro Mujer two years ago through her sister-in-law, who invited her. She currently has a business selling potatoes and  chuño. She says she started this business because she didn't have any money and she wanted to help her husband generate resources by selling regional products.

The loan she is now requesting will be used to increase capital (to purchase potatoes and chuño). She will buy from the rural areas and later sell at the traditional markets in the city of El Alto. This line of work allows her to generate resources in order to support her family as best she can, since she is in a common-law marriage and has four children. 

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says it is the health trainings and the loans.

loans.use: to purchase potatoes and chuño.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
Víctor, es casado y tiene un hijo que está en etapa escolar, viven en la casa de sus padres ocupando dos habitaciones, la casa esta ubicada en la zona Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz.
El estudió hasta terminar la secundaria y actualmente obtiene ingresos ya que cuenta con un puesto alquilado de venta de celulares, pues debe cubrir los gastos de alimentación, educación y pago de servicios básicos de su familia. Victor  trabaja por más de diez horas al día y con lo poco que gana no le alcanza para pagar sus estudios es por eso que solicita el crédito ya que desea pagar la matricula de su instituto donde estudia  mantenimiento y reparación de teléfonos celulares.
El sueño de Víctor, es tener su tienda propia de celulares ya que desea mejorar sus ingresos para poder independizarse y dar más comodidad a su familia.
Es la primera vez que trabaja junto a IMPRO y KIVA.
texts.en:
Víctor is married and has a son who is school age.  They live in his parents’ house occupying two rooms.  The house is located in the city of La Paz’s Pasankeri zone.

He completed secondary school and currently earns income because he has a rented stand where he sells mobile phones because he must cover his family’s basic education, food and utility expenses.  Víctor works more than ten hours daily and the little he earns is insufficient for him to pay for his education which is why he’s asking for a loan because he wants to pay tuition at an institute where he’s studying mobile phone maintenance and repair.

Víctor’s dream is to have his own mobile phone store because he wants to improve his income in order to become independent and give more comfort to his family.

This is the first time he’s worked with Impro and with Kiva.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees.

loans.name: Alejandro Gabino

texts.es:
Alejandro es un hombre de 33 años, es soltero, vive en la ciudad de Camaná, él es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo por salir adelante y ayudar a sus padres, a quienes desea retribuirles todos sus cuidados y apoyo brindado; lamentablemente por tener la necesidad de trabajar y solventar sus gastos no pudo cursar una carrera profesional, pero le hubiera gustado poder estudiar la carrera de Ingeniería Civil, en sus ratos libres le gusta jugar futbol con sus hermanos y vecinos, y en alguna de estas ocasiones aprovechan estar reunidos para comer un riquísimo Chupe de Camarones.
Gracias a su espíritu emprendedor y al apoyo de su familia, Alejandro se desempeña en el rubro de la construcción, él es maestro de obras, desde tempranas horas de la mañana Alejandro dedica un aproximado de 10 horas diarias a su labor, mensualmente puede atender un promedio de 8 clientes; él se encuentra a gusto realizando su trabajo ya que su Padre le enseñó el arte de la construcción y él desea seguir con la tradición familiar.   
Alejandro se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de materiales para sus obras, tales como: maderas, clavos, cubos, sogas, entre otros; de esta manera Alejandro podrá contar con las herramientas necesarias para realizar su trabajo y con ello espera poder atender a mas clientes e incrementar su ingresos económicos, con los cuales en un futuro no muy lejano desea poder adquirir una mototaxi para adicionalmente trabajar en ella y así poder seguir ayudando a su familia.
texts.en:
Alejandro is a 33-year-old, single man who lives in the town of Camaná.  He is a very friendly, hard-working, enthusiastic person who has a great desire to make progress in life and help his parents.  He would like to return all the care and support his parents have given to him over the years.  Unfortunately, because he needed to work and cover his expenses, Alejandro was not able to study for a degree.  He would have liked to have studied to become a civil engineer.  In his free time, he enjoys playing soccer with his siblings and neighbors.  Sometimes they make the most of being together and enjoy eating delicious 'chupe de camarones' together.

Thanks to his entrepreneurial spirit and the support of his family, Alejandro works in the building trade.  He is a master builder.  He gets up early in the morning and works around 10 hours a day in his job.  He can serve an average of 8 customers a month.  He is happy in his work because his father taught him the art of building and he would like to continue in the family tradition.

Alejandro is very grateful to Kiva lenders because, thanks to their help, he will be able to buy the materials he needs for his work such as wood, nails, buckets, ropes, etc.  This will allow him to have all the tools he needs to carry out his work.  He hopes that it will enable him to serve more customers and increase his income.  In the not-so-distant future he would like to use this money to buy a motorcycle taxi so that he can work with it as well and continue helping his family.

loans.use: to buy materials such as wood, nails, buckets, ropes, etc.

loans.name: Elina

texts.en:
Elina is married with six children. She has been a maize farmer for 7 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to pay school fees for her children.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha, 37, is a married mother; she has five children, all in school, and lives in the town of Msambweni, Kenya.
She is very hardworking. She’s been selling foodstuffs such as dumplings and flat breads, selling mostly in the mornings and evenings, in an open air market. Mwanasha has been in this business for the last two years. She lives in a house together with her family. From this business she earns income needed for her children’s schooling and for household expenses.

Her goal is to see the business better stocked and to use profits to cover her children’s schooling costs until they graduate and to manage to acquire a house of her own. She will use this loan to buy wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is married with one child, three years old. He has been a maize farmer for 7 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to renovate the house. 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Laurent

texts.en:
Laurent is married with two children aged 6 and 7; both of the children attend school. His wife is also a maize farmer. He has been a maize farmer for 6 years. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to renovate his house.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is married and has four children. Her husband works as a maize farmer as well. She has been a maize farmer for 10 years. She wants a loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. She wants to use the profits to build a house.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Luz Berenice

texts.es:
Luz es una persona muy trabajadora que siempre ha querido aportar a su familia recursos económicos con el ánimo de tener una mejor calidad de vida en el hogar y mejores oportunidades económicas. Luz se encuentra casada y tiene 2 hijos de 10 y 18 años de edad a quienes siempre ha querido darles el acceso a una educación de buena calidad, por esto trabaja fuertemente con el ánimo de tener recursos económicos para hacer este deseo realidad. Tiene una tienda general la cual montó gracias a que su padre es el dueño del local y un hermano le colaboró con el capital inicial, y desde entonces esta ha sido un gran apoyo económico para toda su familia. A pesar de que tiene muy buenas ventas y cada vez le va mejor en su negocio, también ha tenido que atravesar por adversidades que hacen muy difícil el progreso de su familia; hace unos meses unos ladrones se entraron a su tienda y le robaron algunos activos de la misma y dinero en efectivo, lo cual ha venido recuperando poco a poco con un trabajo muy fuerte. Con el ánimo de mejorar la atención que ofrece a sus clientes y recuperar sus activos, Luz busca que un préstamo le permita comprar una vitrina y surtir su tienda con productos de la canasta familiar.

De esta manera logrará superar las adversidades que se le han presentado y su familia seguirá teniendo unos buenos ingresos con los cuales disfrutará de una mejor calidad de vida y una mejor estabilidad económica en el hogar.
texts.en:
Luz is a very hard-working person who has always wanted to contribute to her family's finances, with the aim of having a better quality of life in the home and better economic opportunities. 

Luz is married and has two children, ages 10 and 18, to whom she has always wanted to give access to a good quality education. This is why she works hard to have the financial resources to make this wish a reality.

She has a general store that she set up thanks to the fact that her father is the owner of the premises. A brother contributed the initial working capital.  Since then, the store has been a great financial support for the entire family.  

In spite of the fact she has very good sales, and it is going better and better for her in her business, she has had to experience hardships that make it very difficult for her family to move forward. A few months ago, thieves entered her store and stole some assets and cash. 

She has been gradually recovering by working very hard. With the aim of improving the service she offers her customers and recovering her assets, Luz is seeking a loan to allow her to buy a display case and supply her store with basic household products.

This way she will manage to overcome the hardships that have arisen, and her family will continue having good income with which they will enjoy a better quality of life and better fiinancial stability in the home.

loans.use: To buy a display case and supply her store with basic household products.

loans.name: Las Favoritas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LAS FAVORITAS” iniciará el sexto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Cascada, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Romualda es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: corte de ladrillos, pensión, inicio de salchipapería, transporte público, venta de ropa interior, venta de chompas, tienda de barrio.

La señora Romualda, indica que hace cuatro años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una amiga. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de artesanías (tejido de mantas), ella cuenta que hace cinco años atrás realizaba tejido de chompas conjuntamente su hermana y poco a poco ingreso al tejido de mantas que es más beneficioso económicamente.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para la ampliación de su capital (compra de lana) mismo que comprará de las distribuidoras de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo venderá en su espacio de venta todas las tardes. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene un hijo.  

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta estar con las compañeras.
texts.en:
The “LAS FAVORITAS” community bank are about to start their sixth loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Cascada regional office.  The group has eight members and is run by a board of directors which has Romualda as its treasurer.  The businesses that the members are engaged in are varied and include: making bricks, running a food business, starting a 'salchipapa' (fast food) business, providing public transport, selling underwear, selling sweaters and running a neighborhood store.

Romualda says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for four years, having joined when she received an invitation from a friend.  She currently has a craft business (knitting blankets).  She says that five years ago she used to knit sweaters together with her sister but gradually started knitting blankets as it makes more money.

Romualda will use the loan she is about to take out to expand her capital (buying yarn).  She will buy her yarn from suppliers in the city of El Alto.  After she has made her products she will sell them in her sales location every afternoon.  This work allows her to make income with which to support her family.  She is married and has one child.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Romualda replied that she likes spending time with her fellow group members.

loans.use: to buy yarn

loans.name: José

texts.es: Por tradición la familia de José se ha dedicado por generaciones al cultivo del café. Desde que él era pequeño su padre le enseñó a trabajar a él y sus hermanos en las fincas de café, haciendo labores diversas. Con el paso de los años José aprendió todo lo necesario para convertirse en productor de café y cuando se caso su padre le heredó un terreno y se independizó. José enseñó a sus hijos a trabajar en el campo y aunque ya todos están casados aún le ayudan en los trabajos de limpieza y corte. José produce tanto café orgánico como convencional y le gustaría poder convertir toda su producción a orgánico. Para llevar esto a cabo es necesario reemplazar muchas de las plantas que ya tienen sembradas y por eso él está solicitando un crédito. Este proceso le tomará de 2 a 3 años y por eso lo ira realizando por etapas para que así no baje su nivel de producción. José ha estado ahorrando dinero junto con sus hijos pues desean comprar más terrenos para así poder aumentar su producción y su patrimonio.
texts.en:
José's family have been growing coffee for generations.  It is a family tradition.  When he was little, his father taught him and his siblings to work on the coffee plantations, carrying out a number of different jobs.  Over the years, José learned all he needed to know in order to become a coffee producer.  When he got married, his father gave him a plot of land and he started working for himself.  José taught his children to work the land and, although they are all now married, they still help him with his weeding and cutting.

José grows both organic and conventional coffee.  He would like to convert all his production to organic.  In order to achieve this, he needs to replace many of the plants that he currently has growing.  This is why he is requesting a loan.  The process will take him 2 to 3 years and he will carry out the work in stages so that his production levels do not decrease.  José has been saving money together with his children as they would like to buy more land so that they can increase their production and their assets.

loans.use: to buy coffee plants

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
This is Nelly, 33, a resident of Tanza,Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Felicito, a contractor. She is also mother to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nelly operates a tube retailing business. What she basically does is buy tube ice from ice manufacturing plants and sell them with a little profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippines Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy additional supply of tube ice and styrofoam boxes to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Nelly hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supply of tube ice and styrofoam boxes needed in her business.

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is married with one child, aged 3. His wife works as a businesswoman. He has been a maize farmer for three years. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to renovate his house.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and suppport labor costs.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 56 years old and is a widow with six children between 14 and 25 years old. For the past ten years, she has been selling sorghum. She currently employs four people to help her. 

Beatrice is requesting a Kiva loan via the Vision Finance Company to buy large quantities of sorghum for resale. She will save the profits from her loan for the future to pay school fees for her children and she will be able to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of sorghum for resale.

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange is 30 years old and is married with two children, two and five years old. For the past four years she has been selling jerrycans. She currently employs three people to help her and her work runs from 6 a.m to 6 p.m every day except on Sunday. 

Solange is requesting a Kiva loan via the Vision Finance Company to buy more jerrycans for resale. She will save the profits from her loan for the future and she will be able to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy more jerrycans for resale.

loans.name: Shakira

texts.en:
Shakira is 34 years old and is married with three children between two and seven years old. For the past five years she has been selling local drinks. She currently employs two people to help her and her work runs from 5 a.m to 9 p.m every day. 

Shakira is requesting a Kiva loan via the Vision Finance Company to purchase large quantities of sorghum to make local drinks for resale. She will save the profits from her loan for the future and she will be able to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase large quantities of sorghum to make local drinks for resale.

loans.name: Lumturi

texts.en:
Lumturi is forrty-two years old and married. She has five children ranging from twenty to twelve years old with all of them attending school. They live in a rocky village in the central eastern part of Albania. The business that Lumturi has been involved in for the past ten years and more has been agriculture and livestock. She owns goats and makes delicious cheese and cottage cheese. The business and clientele have been showing some stability so far. However, being the only one to support her family financially makes it difficult for her to put some money aside. 
Now she wants to expand her business by adding twenty more goats to her herd. For help with this, she seeks Kiva lenders’ understanding. Lumturi is planning to use the profit from her business not only to educate her children, but to improve their living conditions as well.
Lumturi is thanking every potential lender in advance.

loans.use: to add twenty goats to her herd.

loans.name: Therese

texts.en: Therese is 62. She is a widow with four children between 20 and 33 years old. All of them go to school. She has been selling foodstuffs for the past 20 years. The loan requested will be used to buy more beans and honey to sell. The profits from the business will be used pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: to buy more beans and honey to sell.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en: Jeanne is 32 years old. She is a mother of six children aged between 1 and 16 years. She wants this loan to buy more wood because she has been running a woodworking shop for 8 months. With the profits from the business, she will buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy more wood for making timbers.

loans.name: Marilu

texts.es: La señora Marilú es madre soltera de tres hijos y con ellos vive su madre y su hermana la cual le ayuda en su pequeño negocio de barrotes y asi no descuida a sus hijos ya que los niños adoran a la abuelita. Necesita surtir su tienda porque la temporada estubo muy baja de ganacias y le resulta muy dificil surtir porque si compra en tiendas cercas como tiendas de autoservicio le sale mas caro y en cambio cuando compra al mayoreo es cuando las ganacias suben. Despues de que esta mejora se encuntre realizaada sus clientes perduraran y seguira generando los ingresos y así sostener su gran familia que la necesita. Ella tiene más de 8 años con el negocio y poco a poco lo ha hecho crecer ella y su familia.
texts.en: Marilú is a single mother and she has three children. She lives with them, her mother and her sister who helps her running her small general store. This was her children can be cared for by their grandmother, whom they adore.  She needs to stock-up her store because last season was very slow and it is difficult to restock her store if she has to buy from local expensive stores.  On the other hand, buying wholesale allows her to make more money.  After she is able to realize this improvement her customers will continue to shop at her store and she will continue earning the income she needs to provide for her large family.  She has been running her shop for more than 8 years, and little by little this activity has favored both her personal growth and her family’s progress.

loans.use: To buy products for her shop.

loans.name: Generación 2006 Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “GENERACIÓN 2006” iniciará el noveno ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Jhosselin Daniela es la Secretaria. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de ropa, venta de pantuflas, tienda de abarrotes, comerciante de añelina, venta de productos de YAMBAL, múltiples de abarrotes, venta de productos diversos, tallado en madera.

La señora Jhoselin Daniela, indica que hace siete meses que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de su hermana que es socia desde hace tiempo. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de artículos varios (zapatones, guantes, gorros, chalinas y paraguas) ella cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió  de su madre hace años.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el incremento de capital (compra de gorros, guantes, zapatones, etc.) mismo que comprará de las ferias reconocidas de la Ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo venderá en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The “GENERACIÓN 2006” community bank are about to start their ninth loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Villa Exaltación regional office.  The group has eight members and is run by a board of directors which has Jhosselin Daniela as its secretary.  The businesses that the members are engaged in are varied and include: selling clothes, selling slippers, running a grocery store, selling 'añelina' (a dye), selling Yambal products, selling groceries, selling miscellaneous merchandise and wood carving.

Jhosselin Daniela says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for seven months, having joined through an invitation from her sister who has been a member for some time.  She currently has a business selling a range of different goods (booties, gloves, hats, scarves and umbrellas).  She says that she took over this business from her mother some years ago.  

The loan that Jhosselin Daniela is currently requesting will be used to increase her capital (she will buy hats, gloves, slippers, etc.)  She will buy these products in the well-known street fairs in the city of La Paz and then sell them from her sales location.  This work enables her to make income with which to support her family.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Jhosselin Daniela replied that she likes the health training and the loans.

loans.use: to buy hats, gloves, slippers etc.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: El señor Luis solicita un credito para pagar las inscripciones de uno de sus hijos a la preparatoria y al no hacerlo a tiempo su hijo puede quedar sin estudiar y el no desea que por no poder pagar la inscripcion su hijo se quede sin entrar a la escuela. El señor Luis trabaja en una gasolinera en el turno de la noche, mientras que su esposa se dedica al cuidado de sus hijos y las labores de la casa. Para él ha sido muy dificil sostener su casa ya que solo entra su sueldo. Ambos formaron una hermosa y gran familia y día a día se esfuerzan en poder brindarles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en: Luis is requesting a loan to pay for high school registration fees of one of his children, because if he does not pay the enrollment fee on time his son runs the risk of not being admitted to school, but he does not want his child to renounce studying because he cannot afford to pay. Luis works the night shift in a gas station, while his wife is a housewife and she care for their children and engages in the daily chores of a house. It has been difficult to maintain the household with only one salary. They have formed a very big and beautiful family, and they do their best on a daily basis in order to offer the best to their children.

loans.use: To pay for high school registration fees of one of his children.

loans.name: Estelar Group

texts.es:
EL GRUPO ESTELAR ES UN GRUPO SOLIDARIO DE CREDITUYO ESTA INTEGRADO POR 6 INTEGRANTES  SUS NOMBRES SON 
JESSIKA ,NADIA (Not Pictured), ROSA,  YOLANDA MARICARMEN  Y LAURA ELLAS SON VECINAS Y AMIGAS,SE CONOCEN DESDE HACE VARIOS AÑOS SE TIENEN MUCHA CONFIANZA POR ESO DECIDIERON FORMAR EL GRUPO. TODAS SE DEDICAN AL COMERCIO.

LA SEÑORA YOLANDA ES UNA DE LAS INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO, TIENE 64 AÑOS DE EDAD TIENE 4 HIJOS YA CASADOS  ELLA SOLO VIVIE CON SU ESPOSO, ELLA TIENE UN NEGOCIO DE ABARROTES , SU CREDITO PIENSA UTILIZARLO EN COMPRAR,MAS MERCANCIA PARA SU NEGOCIO COMO ABARROTES Y LATERIA, EL SUEÑO DE LA SEÑORA YOLANDA, ES TENER EL NEGOCIO MAS GRANDE DE SU COMUNIDAD, TENERLO BIEN SURTIDO PARA PODER VIVIR BIEN ELLA Y SU ESPOSO.YA QUE POR SU EDAD NO LE DAN EMPLEO Y QUIERE TRABAJAR DESDE SU HOGAR PARA PODER CONVIVR CON SUS NIETOS Y QUE ELLOS LA AYUDEN EN EL NEGOCIO.
texts.en:
Grupo Stellar is a borrowing group with [Kiva's field partner] Credituyo. It comprises 6 members: Jessika, Nadia (not pictured), Rosa, Yolanda, Maricarmen, and Laura. They are friends and neighbors who have known each other for several years. They have great confidence in one another, which is why they decided to form their group. All of them are dedicated to trading.

Yolanda is one of the group. She is 64 years old, married with 4 children, and lives with her husband. She has a general store, and intends to use the loan to buy more merchandise, such as groceries and canned goods. Yolanda's dream is to have the largest store in the neighborhood, well stocked, and to use her income to live well with her husband. At her age she is not able to find employment, and wants to work from home so she can be with her grandchildren, who help her in the store.

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock their business

loans.name: Inomjon

texts.en:
For more than 10 years, Inomjon has run his own business. As he is very smart and clever his business has developed year by year. He is busy with this agriculture business. He grows potatoes. Some years ago, he went to Russia to work but there he did not find a good job. He returned to his town and continued his business. 

Inomjon has a friendly family. His wife helps with his business. They have three children and do their best for them. He wants to develop his business further. He is asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizers for the land on which he works. He awaits your help and support.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
Ly, 49, is a villager living in Mongkol Borey district, a part of Battambang Province. She is a mother of five children, two of whom she still supports. For the past ten years Ly’s rice paddy has been her main source of income. She also sells her handmade fans. From these activities she earns about 21,000 KHR a day.

Ly has been with VisionFund for six loan cycles. The past loan, which she successfully repaid, has enabled her to improve her living conditions, stabilize her businesses and keep her children in school.

Now Ly has formed a group with another woman to apply for a new loan of 600,000 KHR each. As the group leader, she will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and materials for making her fans. She hopes to earn more income and make a better living from these businesses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm and materials for her fans.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkol Borey District

loans.name: Richfold

texts.en: Richfold is a married man of 46 years of age. He is a repeat client from Kiruhura district. He began borrowing as a group client and later graduated to individual. Richfold majorly deals in animal sales particularly the goat trade. From that business, he has managed to construct a house up to the roofing level and he now wants money to buy doors and windows for it. Richfold has been renting but now will be able to stay in his own house with his family. He credits all this to Ugafode's Flexible Housing Loan product that has helped him get decent housing.

loans.use: to complete his house.

loans.name: Asifiwe Group

texts.fr: La cliente Furaha est membre du le groupement  d’affaire Asifiwe, jeune  entrepreneur, célibataire, âgée de 21 ans. Elle est vendeuse des denrées alimentaires. Elle fait  également la coupe couture.De lors qu’elle a raté son parcours scolaire, elle a fait la formation de petits métiers. Elle s’entraide avec sa maman dans ces petites activités. Elle est sociétaire d’un atelier de couture. Elle commença son entreprise avec son fonds propre. Plus tard, elle sollicita le soutien de l’IMF Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  4 sacs de haricots, d’arachides, huiles, etc., et une autre somme de crédit sera affectée dans son atelier de couture.  Le grand défi qu’elle connait dans son activité est la multiplicité de taxe. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son appui  et autonomisation des petits entrepreneurs femmes.
texts.en:
Furaha, age 21 and single, is a young entrepreneur and a member of the business group Asifiwe.  She sells food products and also works as a seamstress.  She started to train for small jobs after quitting school.  Her mother helps her in these small activities. 

Furaha is a shareholder in a sewing shop.  She started this business with her own money.  Later on, she turned to the microfinance institution Hekima for financial assistance.

She will use this new loan to buy four sacks of beans, groundnut, oil etc., and invest the rest into funding her sewing shop.  Her major challenge is the amount of taxes that she has to pay.

Furaha thanks Hekima for its support and its actions toward the empowerment of women who want to create their own small businesses.

loans.use: to buy four sacks of beans, groundnut, oil etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Juana Edeytrudes

texts.es: Juana Edytrudes de 51 años de edad tiene por actividad economica la una pulperia ubicada en su casa de habitacion, herramienta que surgio por la necesidad de tener un medio de ingresos de economicos  para su familia, en el cual tiene 6 años de experiencia, con los financaimiento ha podido invertir en capital de trabajo y de dicha forma surtir su pulperia, en esta ocacion esta solicitando el fiananciamiento para comprar productos de consumo diario como : arroz, azucar, café, pan, leche, huevos, frijoles, tiste, chicha, crema, condimentos, verduras, galletas, entre otros.
texts.en:
Juana Edytrudes is 51 years old and manages a store in her home.  This business was started out of necessity so that she could have a source of income for her family.  She now has six years of experience.  

This loan will provide her with operating capital to invest in inventory for her store.  On this occasion, the loan she requested will be used to buy everyday consumer products such as rice, sugar, coffee, bread, milk, eggs, beans, "tiste" (a popular Nicaraguan beverage made from corn and cacao), "chicha" (another beverage made from corn), cream, condiments, vegetables, cookies, and other items.

loans.use: to buy a variety of products for her store.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: El Sr. José Luis es originario el estado de Nuevo León.  Radica en Nuevo Laredo desde hace más de 30 años y desde hace más de 15 años que se dedica a la elaboración y venta de piñatas y artesanías las cuales son exportadas a estados unidos.  Lo apoyan en el negocio su esposa e hijo, con ello produce empleo a 2 personas.  Con el ingreso de su negoción es con lo que solventa todos los gastos familiares y del mismo negocio. El Sr. José Luis solicita el préstamo para comprar y abastecerse de suficiente materia prima para fabricar piñatas y artesanías que se envían a estados unidos y así seguir dando trabajo  a personas que tanto lo necesitan y lo mas importante para el es cuidar y brindar lo necesario a su familia
texts.en: José Luis is originally from the state of Nuevo León. He has resided in Nuevo Laredo for over thirty years and for over fifteen years he has been making and selling piñatas and handicrafts, which are exported to the United States. His wife and son help him with his business. This way he creates jobs for two people. He uses the income from his business to cover all of the family expenses as well as the business' own expenses. José Luis is requesting the loan in order to purchase and stock up on enough raw material to make piñatas and handicrafts, which are sent to the US, so that he can continue giving employment to people who so badly need it. The most important thing to him is taking care of his family and providing what they need.

loans.use: to purchase raw material.

loans.name: Mario Ezequiel

texts.es: Mario Ezequiel, casado de 56 años de edad,  con tres hijos mayores, tiene por actividad económica  una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación ,inicio con esta herramienta hace 11 años por la necesidad que tenia de tener un ingresos para su familia, en la actualidad sigue luchado por el pan de cada día junto a su negocio el cual le ha sido rentable por mucho años, el financiamiento lo está solicitando para invertir en productos de consumo diario como:  arroz, azúcar, pan, leche de vaca, leche de bolsas, jugos naturales, gaseosas,  caramelos, churritos, entre otros.
texts.en: Mario Ezequiel is 56 years old, married, and has three grown-up children.  His business is a grocery store which is located in his home.  He started this business eleven years ago as he needed to make income for his family.  He continues working hard to provide for his daily needs through his business which has been profitable for many years.  He is requesting a loan to invest in basic household products such as rice, sugar, bread, cows' milk, powdered milk, natural juices, soda, candies, churritos, etc.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, bread, cows' milk, powdered milk, natural juices, soda, candies, churritos, etc.

loans.name: Luz Mery

texts.es: Luz Mary de 45 años de edad es la propietaria de un negocio de variedades, con el que apoya el  mejoramiento del bienestar de su hogar conformado por su esposo que está en la misma dinámica de producir y sus hijos en las edades de 24 y 19 años, con quienes sueña esta pareja verlos convertidos en profesionales exitosos. Su actividad como comerciante data dese hace 10 años, cuando una consultora de productos cosméticos comercializados mediante guías especializadas, la incorporó a su catalogo y ella inició con un mercado doméstico conformados con sus vecinos, parientes y allegados. Muy pronto sus esfuerzos de promoción, venta y recuperación de la inversión generaron sus frutos de crecimiento empresarial y hoy es ella la directora de productos de marcas y lidera un grupo de más de 60 mujeres que comercializan cosméticos, variedades femenina y perfumería. Así mismo ha ganado premios y ha invertido mucho en los productos que la revista promociona con descuentos, lo cual la llevó hace 5 años a comprar vitrina y estantería  que ubicó en su propia casa como un punto comercial y le ha ido muy bien, pues ha logrado agregar otros artículos, que compra porque le demandan su exclusiva clientela. Cuando compró un computador para su familia, los clientes vecinos le pedían prestado el computador o les trascribiera cartas y comunicados en general; por eso ella observando esta necesidad pot4encial forma de generar ingresos adicionó a su negocio el servicio de transcripciones y fotocopiaje donde también le ha ido muy bien y su mayor meta es lograr el crecimiento de su microempresa. Por eso todas las mañanas se levanta con este ánimo y dirige todos sus esfuerzos reflejado en disciplina de trabajo, para lograr su propósito principal, aunque su mayor desafío es no tener el suficiente capital de trabajo, para invertir prontamente en él, pues el mayor volumen de ventas las hace a crédito. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará una impresora, una vitrina, mercancía en general como  perfumes y cosméticos. Con esta inversión mejorará sus ingresos y poco a poco logrará el sueño de lograr que su hijo termine sus estudios universitarios.
texts.en:
Luz Mery is 45 years old and owns a multi-service business.  This allows her to support her household which consists of her husband, who is also an entrepreneur, and their children who are 24 and 19 years old.  She dreams of seeing her children become successful professionals.  Luz Mery started her business 10 years ago when a cosmetics consultant who sold products through specialized guides introduced her to her catalog and she started selling goods to a market consisting of neighbors, relatives and close friends.  Her efforts in promoting and selling her products, and recouping her investment, were very soon rewarded as her business grew.  She is now a product director and leads a group of more than 60 women who sell cosmetics, ladies' accessories and perfumes.  She has earned prizes and has invested a lot in the products that the catalog promotes with discounts.  As a result, five years ago she was able to buy a display case and shelving which she set up in her own home, turning it into a sales location.  Things have gone very well and she has managed to start selling additional products which she buys because her customers request them.

When Luz Mery bought a computer for her family, her neighbors and customers would ask to borrow it or ask her to type letters and general memos.  She saw a potential for making income and added a transcription and photocopying service to her business.  This has also done very well and Luz Mery's biggest goal is now to grow her micro-business.  In order to achieve her goal, she gets up every morning and puts all her efforts into her work.  Her main challenge is not having enough working capital to invest in her business as she makes most of her sales on credit.  This is why she is requesting a Kiva loan (her first loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo).  She will use her loan to buy a printer, a display case and general merchandise such as perfumes and cosmetics.  This investment will improve her income and she will gradually manage to fulfill her dream of seeing her son finish university.

loans.use: to buy a printer, a display case and general merchandise such as perfumes and cosmetics

loans.name: Naim

texts.en:
Naim is from Kosovo. He is single and lives with extended family. To make a living, Naim owns and operates a transportation business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing transport goods such as wood and furniture to local members of the community. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns enough from these activities to support the needs of his family.

Being the only financial provider for his family, he has not been able to save money for the bad days. This is why Naim, for the first time, is requesting a Kiva loan through KosInvest to repair a transport vehicle and to buy new wheels.

Naim plans to use the revenue from the business to improve his family's living conditions. He is grateful to KosInvest and Kiva lenders and will continue to work hard to grow his business.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle and to buy new wheels.

loans.name: Seth

texts.en:
Seth is married with eight children. His wife works as a farmer. He has been an Irish potato grower for 10 years. He would like to get this loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, and to support labor costs in order to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers, seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is married with one child of seven months. His wife works as a farmer. He has been an Irish potato grower for seven years. He would like to get this loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, and support labor costs in order to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output and build a house near the trading center for commercial purposes.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers, seeds and support for labor costs.

loans.name: Marianne

texts.en:
Marianne is married with three children aged between 16 and 30 years-old. All of them go to school. She has been an Irish potato grower for 40 years. She would like to get this loan in order to buy fertilizers, seeds, and to support labor costs in order to get the best harvest. With the profits, she plans to expand the area she has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers, seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Felicien

texts.en:
Felicien is married with eight children. His wife works as a farmer. He has been an Irish potato grower for 20 years. He would like to get this loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, and to support labor costs in order to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output and buy a cow to provide milk.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers, seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is married with five children. His wife works as a farmer. He has been an Irish potato grower for 15 years. He would like to get this loan to buy fertilizers, seeds, and support his labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers, seeds, and support labor costs

loans.name: San Sebastián Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama San Sebastián, está conformado por once mujeres originarias de un pueblo llamado San Sebastián Ixcapa, los platillos típicos de este lugar son el mole de pollo y guajolote.
Una de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora Severina mejor como conocida como Doña Seve de treinta y seis años de edad. Doña Seve se dedica a la venta comida y refrescos en un pequeño local que está ubicado en el parque de su comunidad. Doña Seve es madre soltera y dice que gracias a su negocio, ha podido darles una buena educación a sus hijos Coral Guadalupe, Luz María y José Antonio quienes la apoyan en los momentos más difíciles. Doña Seve menciona que debido al gran número de clientes que tieney a que sus ganancias son muy buenas, decidió construir su casa y darles un patrimonio a sus hijos. Ella inició su negocio gracias a la ayuda de su mamé pues fue ella quien le heredo el local donde actualmente vende su comida.

Doña Seve dice que se considera una persona especial porque le gusta mucho trabajar y no depender de otras personas para lograr sus sueños. Pidió el crédito para comprar refrescos e ingredientes para la elaboración de los platillos: chile verde, chile seco, tomate, cebolla, queso, carnes frías y aceite. Uno de los deseos de doña Seve es que todas las madres solteras se valoren y luchen por sus sueños. Le da las gracias a Vision Found por ayudarla para que su negocio crezca.

Las otras integrantes de este grupo son:

Reyna- se dedica a la venta de pan.
Gabriela- se dedica a la venta de comida.
Marcelina Socorro- se dedica a la venta de carnes frías.
Maris Mavi – se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Martha- se  dedica a la venta de comida.
Pabla- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Herma- se dedica a la venta de pan.
Bernarda- se dedica a la venta de cernes fría.
Agueda- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Enedina- se dedica a la venta de mercancía de abarrotes.
texts.en:
The group called "San Sebastián" consists of 11 women who are originally from the town of San Sebastián Ixcapa.  The traditional dishes from this area include chicken and turkey with mole sauce.  

One of the members of this group is Sra. Severina, better known as Doña Seve.  She is 36 years of age.  Doña Seve sells food and soft drinks from a small shop located in the community park.  She is a single mother who says, thanks to her business, she is able to provide a good education for her children:  Coral Guadalupe, Luz María, and José Antonio.  They have supported her during the most difficult moments.  Doña Seve mentions that she has a large number of customers, so her earnings have been very good.  She decided to build a house so that she could leave an inheritance for her children.  Thanks to her mother, she was given a shop where she could start her business and is currently selling food.  

Doña Seve says that she considers herself to be a special person because she enjoys working and is not dependent on other people as she fulfills her dreams.  She is requesting a loan in order to buy soft drinks and ingredients for preparing her dishes such as green chili peppers, dried chili peppers, onions, cheese, cold cuts, and oil.  One of her wishes is for all single mothers to value themselves and strive for their dreams.  She thanks Vision Fund for helping her with growing her business.    

The other group members are as follows:
• Reyna sells bread.
• Gabriela sells food
• Marcelina Socorro sells cold cuts.
• Maris Mavi sells Mexican street food.
• Martha sells food.
• Pabla sells Mexican street food.
• Herma sells bread.
• Bernarda sells cold cuts.  
• Agueda sells Mexican street food.
• Enedina sells groceries.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and ingredients for preparing her dishes.

loans.name: Las Ardillas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama  Las Ardillas esta conformado por diez mujeres trabajadores nacidas en la ciudad de Pinotepa Nacional, Oaxaca, mejor conocida como tierra de oportunidades.

Una de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora Xochilt Guillermina, mejor conocida como doña Xochilt (que significa "flor" en Náhuatl). Doña Xochilt de treinta y ocho años de edad, se dedica a la venta de moldes de plástico por catálogo desde hace dos años y seis meses, para ella, su negocio es lo mejor que le ha pasado ya que con sus ganancias ha podido tener una mejor calidad de vida. Doña Xochilt menciona que lo que más le gusta de su negocio es salir a ofrecer su mercancía y relacionarse con sus clientes. Por otro lado, lo que representa mayor reto para ella es que en ocasiones sus clientes no tienen dinero para pagarle por la mercancía que ya adquirieron, lo que hace que Doña Xochilt pierda ganancias y tiempo. Ella decidió tener su negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y para ofrecer entre los dos, una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.

Doña Xochilt se considera una persona especial porque le gusta mucho superarse, superar obstáculos y barreras que encuentra en su camino, ya que cuando está triste, piensa en su valor como persona y lo que significa su negocio para ella. Doña Xochilt dice que cuando ha establecido una meta, da lo mejor de sí para cumplirla. Ella pidió su crédito para la compra de más moldes de plástico para vender por mayoreo y menudeo.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son:

Martina- se dedica a la venta de carnes frías.
Maricela- se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Paz Daniela- se dedica a la venta de pan.
Candida Blanca - se dedica a la venta de ropa.
Marisol- se dedica a la venta de bisutería.
María Antonia- se dedica a la venta de materiales para la construcción.
Patricia- se dedica a la venta de calzado.
María Elena- se dedica a la venta de ropa.
Abith – se dedica a la venta de calzado.

Le dan las gracias a Vision Fund por ayudar a todas las mujeres emprenderos y exitosas.
texts.en:
This group is called 'Las Ardillas' (The Squirrels).  It is made up of ten hard-working women who were born in the town of Pinotepa Nacional, in Oaxaca, better known as 'the land of opportunity'.

One of the members of this group is Xochilt Guillermina, better known as Xochilt (which means 'flower' in Nahuatl).  Xochilt is 38 years old and she has been selling plastic containers through a catalog for two and a half years.
